metadata.case_name: M/s. Ram Chand Jagadish Chand v. Union of India

facts.text: Controls on exports and imports imposed during last war kept alive by Emergency Provisions Continuance Ordinance, 1946, replaced by Imports and Exports Control Act, 1947.
Section 3 of Imports and Exports Control Act, 1947 authorised Central Government to prohibit, restrict or control import/export of goods by order in Official Gazette.
Sub-sec (2) of s.3 provided goods under such order deemed prohibited/restricted under s.19 of Sea Customs Act.
Central Government issued notifications prohibiting/restricting exports/imports; Consolidated order dated December 7, 1955 as Imports Control Order, 1955.
Cl. 3 of Imports Control Order, 1955: No person shall import goods in Schedule I except under licence or customs clearance permit.
Government issues Import Trade Control Policy every six months in Gazette, published as handbook; framed considering home consumption, foreign exchange, economy.
Para 51 of Import Trade Control Policy (Oct 1958-Mar 1959): Export Promotion Scheme for imports based on value of specified exports.

Appendix 42, cl.2: Licences for artsilk yarn to exporters up to 66-2/3% for sarees, 100% for other artsilk fabrics/hosiery based on rupee equivalent of f.o.b. value or customs assessed value, whichever less.
Petitioners M/s. Ram Chand Jagadish Chand: firm engaged in exporting/importing.
Oct 1958-Mar 1959: Petitioners exported to Singapore Bush Shirt Cloth, Glass Nylon, Art silk Piece Goods, Superior Class Nylon total C.I.F. value Rs. 7,10,817/-.
Petitioners claimed earned net foreign exchange Rs. 7,07,709.55 np. from exports, entitled to import licences for artsilk yarn of that amount under Export Promotion Scheme.
Petitioners called upon Controller of Imports for licences Rs. 4,04,218.62 np. (Feb 1959) and Rs. 3,03,490.93 np. (Mar 1959).
Sep 1959: Informed consolidated licence for Feb-Mar 1959 granted for Rs. 3,19,354/- only.

Govt learned of malpractices in artsilk yarn imports; suspended Export Promotion Scheme from Mar 9, 1959; pending applications to be scrutinised by Committee appointed May 1959 for verification of export values.

Petitioners appeared before Committee, furnished evidence for 100% claim; Committee accepted rates for Flock Printed Nylon Dyed cloth but for Bush Shirt Cloth, valued at Re. 1.50 np. per yard of 36" width.
Controller accepted Committee recommendation, issued licence Rs. 3,19,354/-; petitioners demanded full value but infructuous.
Petitioners filed writ petition under Art. 32 for mandamus to grant full licence or certiorari to quash existing one.

Malpractices: Exporters inflated artsilk fabrics values >100% to import speculative artsilk yarn; e.g., 1957: 381k yards Rs.456k (~Rs.2-0L/yd); 1959: 986k yards Rs.28,799k (Rs.2-9-0/yd) despite wholesale index rise only 11%.
Scheme suspended Mar 6, 1959; Committee scrutinised 1106 parties including petitioners.

Committee on petitioners: Purchased Bush Shirt Cloth from various at Rs.3.87-3.92; no description in vouchers/invoices linking to Nylon/Rayon etc.; no justification for prices; correspondence no link; recommended Re.1.50 np/yd.
Petitioners alleged other 8 exporters got 85-100% licences (table in para 22).
Respondents: Licence =100% of reasonable export value; for others, varying reductions e.g. Raghunath Rai Piyarilal 40%; others accepted where justified.

legal_issues.text: Whether reduction of import licence value to approx 45% infringes fundamental right under Art. 19(1)(g) by imposing unreasonable restriction on trade/business.
Whether grant of lower percentage licence to petitioners while others got higher amounts constitutes discrimination under Art. 14.
Whether power under cl.3 Imports Control Order 1955 and Export Promotion Scheme is uncanalised/arbitrary.

petitioner_arguments.text: Controller arbitrarily reduced value of import licence under Export Promotion Scheme, infringing Art.19(1)(g).
Controller bound to grant 100% of export value; failure discriminates as rivals got 85-100%.
Power under cl.3 Imports Control Order uncanalised, unreasonable restriction.
No evidence petitioners inflated prices or had sister concerns abroad; received full export value.

respondent_arguments.text: Power under s.3 Imports Act and cl.2 Export Promotion discretionary 'upto' percentages, not mandatory 100%; exercised reasonably due to malpractices/inflated invoices.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Imports and Exports Control Act s.3; Imports Control Order cl.3,6-9

respondent_arguments.text: Committee found petitioners' evidence unsatisfactory: no linking descriptions, no price justification for Bush Shirt Cloth; valued reasonably at Re.1.50 np/yd; licence=100% reasonable value.
No discrimination: Others' claims accepted where justified; some reduced similarly; Art.14 against arbitrary action among similarly circumstanced.

court_reasoning.text: Art.19(1)(g) subject to reasonable restrictions; Imports Control Order valid, power not uncanalised (governed by policy, cls.6-9 provide hearing).
court_reasoning.key_observation: Authority to high officers, guided by policy.

court_reasoning.text: Cl.2 'upto' confers discretion, not obligation for full 100%; can reduce for forex etc.; exercised reasonably here due to malpractices.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No absolute right to full value.

court_reasoning.text: Scrutiny justified by evidence of inflation/malpractices; no unreasonable restriction.
Committee findings: Petitioners' docs inadequate, no justification for high prices; no independent evidence of higher market rate; not arbitrary.
No discrimination under Art.14: Not similarly circumstanced; others justified or reduced; equals only.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Evidence showed unsatisfactory records for petitioners.

holdings.text: Power under Export Promotion Scheme discretionary 'upto' maximum; no infringement of Art.19(1)(g).
No discrimination under Art.14 as petitioners not similarly circumstanced to others.
Imports Control Order not imposing unreasonable restrictions.

outcome.summary: Petition under Art.32 dismissed; no infringement of Arts.19(1)(g) or 14; licence grant not arbitrary/discriminatory. Intervention application by M/s. M. Shaams and Company dismissed.

key_quotes.text: "the Controller of Imports is authorised to grant licences upto the percentages specified in that clause there is no right thereby created to the exporter to obtain a licence for the full value"
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "A scrutiny of the applications for licences in view of the misuse of the Export Promotion Scheme and granting of licences on the result of such scrutiny cannot be regarded as imposing an unreasonable restriction."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: "Article 14 confers a guarantee of the equal protection of the law-a guarantee against arbitrary discrimination between persons similarly circumstanced"
key_quotes.speaker: court
